title: Little Missenden Walks

images.title: Bikeboy / Little Missenden
images.caption: Little Missenden. Showing the Red Lion Pub and further up the road the Manor House. The name Missenden is derived from the Old English for "where the marsh plants grow". The place is named "Missendene" in the Domesday Book. The London Aylesbury road passed through the village until the C19 when it was bypassed.

images.title: Peter, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Little Missenden from the path up Toby’s Lane. In the center is the tower of St John the Baptist Church and to the right the Manor House can be seen.

images.title: River Misbourne in Little Missenden by Nigel Cox, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Misbourne in Little Missenden

images.title: Pip Rolls / The Green and Red Lion, Little Missenden
images.caption: The Green and Red Lion, Little Missenden

images.title: Des Blenkinsopp / Mill House, Little Missenden
images.caption: Mill House, Little Missenden. It seems hard to believe that the little River Misbourne had enough water to reliably run a mill this size. I'm guessing the chimney on the left was for a boiler added later for auxiliary power.

images.title: Peter, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pond reflections near to the village.

images.title: Pip Rolls / The Lake, Shardeloes Park, Nr Amersham
images.caption: The Lake, Shardeloes Park, Nr Amersham

images.title: Path through wood at Mop End by michael, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path through bluebell wood at Mop End

description: This delightul Buckinghamshire village has some nice country and river walking trails to try. There's also a picturesque village green and a couple of fine old pubs for refreshments afterwards. The church is also noteworthy, dating back to the 13th century it includes some amazing wall paintings. This circular walk from the village takes you to the nearby Shardeloes Lake before visiting the neighbouring village of Holmer Green. The walk starts in the village where you can pick up the South Bucks Way and follow the waymarked footpath east to Shardeloes where there's pretty lakes and views of the River Misbourne. The route then follows a public footpath south west toward Mop End where there are some nice trails through the bluebell woods. From here you head west past Beamond End to the village of Holmer Green. From here you follow Kingstreet Lane north to meet up with the South Bucks Way at Suffolk Bridge. Head east from here and you will soon come back to Little Missenden.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Back in the village The Crown is a good choice for some post walk refreshment. It's a pub of some note having been named ‘Best Country Pub’ in the Good Pub Guide 2019 edition. It has some history too, having been turned into a pub in 1800. They serve high quality food which you can enjoy in the lovely garden area during the warmer months. You can find them at Highmore Cottages, HP7 0RF.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The country and Mop End woodland trails make for a fine dog walk and the Crown mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head west along the South Bucks Way and you could visit the sister village of Great Missenden. The long distance Chiltern Heritage Trail passes through the village, providing the opportunity of visiting several of the highlights of the Chilterns AONB. For more walking ideas in the area see the Chilterns Walks and the Buckinghamshire Walks pages.

display_address: Beamond End Lane, Little Missenden, Missendens Community Board, Hyde Heath, Buckinghamshire, England, HP6 5RW, United Kingdom
